timeline.bodyText:
The whole notion of expected column handles comes from the fact that the PQL end point returns the group by results first before the aggregations. (and that it fails with not having aggregations and thus we have to introduce fake aggregations).
I am wondering if this constraint also holds for the SQL end point ? if not, then I think we should push this method to be abstract here.
timeline.author: agrawaldevesh

replies.bodyText:
Let me double check on that.
From sql endpoint, we removed the constraint, so expectedColumnHandles should be same as columnHandles

timeline.bodyText: Didn't read this too carefully ... this looks like a giant copy paste :-). What's the main change from PQL generation ?
timeline.author: agrawaldevesh

replies.bodyText:
Current major diff is to change TOP to LIMIT.
Here I expect the future change will happen more on SQL side than PQL side, so intentionally to separate both.
I will abstract common parts(selection/filtering) to until functions for now.
replies.author: xiangfu0

replies.bodyText:
extract the common logic to a method.
Currently SELECT/LIMIT clauses are generated differently.
replies.author: xiangfu0

timeline.bodyText:
How should the segment code path change ? I am not sure if the Pinot Servers also understand "SQL" (vs PQL) ? For that matter, I have forgotten whether the Presto Worker does the PQL to Pinot Plan conversion and sends that to the Pinot Servers or how that translation works (perhaps in the Pinot Driver jar).
We may want to double check that and then perhaps disable SQL for the segment code path.
timeline.author: agrawaldevesh

replies.bodyText: Pinot Server query only do select columns from a table. Server query is still the same.
replies.author: xiangfu0

timeline.bodyText: How about renaming this to generatePinotQueryHelper or generatePinotQueryCommon or such to make it clear that this is just a helper function.
timeline.author: agrawaldevesh

timeline.bodyText: Just double checking: In PQL generation we omit the group by columns from the "select expressions". I am assuming that is NOT done in the SQL generation ?
timeline.author: agrawaldevesh

replies.bodyText:
Yes.
PQL omit groupby columns
SQL will return whatever shows in selection expression.
e.g. SELECT count(*) FROM myTable GROUP BY col; will still just return counts without group by col.
replies.author: xiangfu0

timeline.bodyText:
I can only see tests that are deleted here (that perhaps don't belong in the SQL codepath). I don't see any new tests added here.
I am wondering if it makes sense to actually test out the SQL query generation logic ? Things like using orderby-over-aggregation works, 'limit with aggregation", "group by expressions in select clause" and such.
timeline.author: agrawaldevesh

I think aggregation doesn't need to support limit?

In our case, limit will be ignored unless specified for aggregation only query.

Group by's without any aggregations: "select A,  B from Table group by B, A"

I didn't follow this: I thought in the SQL end point, its okay to have a Pinot SQL query like: "select count(1), A, B, Sum(C) from Table group by B, A" ... ie the group by columns's don't have to come before the agg columns. (And thus we don't need expectedColumnIndices). Is that case tested ?
I am curious what is the pinot SQL expected for these presto sql queries:

"select A, B, Count(1), Sum(C) from Table group by B, A"
-"select Count(1), A, Sum(C), B from Table group by B, A"

+

+        extends TestPinotQueryGenerator

+    {
+        return true;
+    }
+
+    @Test
+    public void assertUsingSqlSyntax()
+    {
+        Assert.assertEquals(defaultSessionHolder.getConnectorSession()
+                .getProperty("use_pinot_sql_for_broker_queries", Boolean.class).booleanValue(), true);
+    }
+
+    @Override
+    public String getExpectedAggOutput(String expectedAggOutput, String groupByColumns)

replies.bodyText: This one works. Pinot handles the selection expression ordering and return the results following that.
replies.author: xiangfu0

replies.bodyText:
This method is to override the expected selection clause in the query.
E.g. assume PQL is select Count(1), Sum(C) from Table group by B, A, then in SQL the query will be select B, A, Count(1), Sum(C) from Table group by B, A in order to get same results.
replies.author: xiangfu0

replies.bodyText: Okay, so this implementation of getExpectedAggOutput does not allow mixing of agg and group by columns. It does handle the group by columns to be explicitly present (which is not the case for PQL). But how would the Presto SQL query with mixed group by and aggregation get translated in the SQL endpoint: "select count(1), A, Sum(C), B from Table group by B, A" ? (note that the aggregations and group by columns are intermingled here and you can't clump the two separately)
replies.author: agrawaldevesh

replies.bodyText: The logic is that AggregationNode always have full aggregation/groupby info, and a ProjectNode will handle the assignment. So we can push down another field, say outputColumns, to handle the logic of what to be pushed down in selection.
replies.author: xiangfu0

replies.bodyText: Also SELECT A from Table group by A passes only TableScanNode to PinotPlanOptimizer, I will look into this maybe in next PR.
replies.author: xiangfu0

timeline.bodyText:
Is order by aggregation limit tested ? That's another difference b/w the SQL and the PQL end point. For example, what would be the pinot sql corresponding to this presto sql: "select A, B, Count(1), Sum(C) from Table group by B, A order by SUM(C) ASC limit 3"
Another example: "select A, B, Sum(C) from Table group by B, A order by SUM(C) ASC limit 3"

timeline.bodyText:
I still don't think I am understanding why this is done :-(.
The project node gives us the projections it wants, and we create newSelections (and newOutputs) out of that. So if we use the SQL syntax, why are we retaining what the old selections were ? A comment with some example query/plan when this is needed would certainly help !
If that's the case (that old selections should be retained): Why is not done unconditionally ? Why is it not done by the context ?
In addition, should selections now be a simple HashMap instead of a LinkedHashMap ? There is a new structure outputs to maintain the ordering now.
timeline.author: agrawaldevesh

replies.bodyText:
The reason is newSelections contains the mapping from varRef to rowExpression.
output, groupby, orderby will hold only varRef.
When we try to generate pinot query, the varRef in groupby may not be in output, e.g. select count(*) group by A, in PQL, we expect A is always in selections.
Here in SQL, we need to hold all the mappings somewhere, which is in selections.
Since I somehow don't want to change the logic to generate PQL, I prefer to keep the logic of selection as is
replies.author: xiangfu0

replies.bodyText:
So in theory, can we do this: Make selections be a simple map (not a linked hash map) from varRef to rowExpression. And output is the linked hash set of varRef that says exactly what is actually projected out. And do this for both PQL and SQL endpoints.
ie, in your example above: Both A and count(*) will be in selections, while output will only consist of count(*).  Would that work ?
replies.author: agrawaldevesh

replies.bodyText:
this works for SQL.
For PQL, we still need to figure out the mapping of expected column indices based on group by conventions (PQL always return groupbys first then aggregations).

replies.bodyText: Here the reason is that in our PQL generation test, we create AggregationPlanNode by setting the Aggregations directly, if we use HashMap then generatedPql cannot guarantee the ordering of aggregation functions. Otherwise we need to set a ProjectNode always outside an AggregationPlanNode

So the change I made is to generate outputs in visitAggregation method.

Is it possible to dedup these lines with the one below [532-534] ? Particularly line 524 that creates the PinotColumnHandle.
One possible way would be to do this in two steps: In the first step you partition outputs into: groupByColumns and those that are not in groupByColumns and not hidden. Then you can stitch these two partitions and create the column handles in one pass from them. Not sure how much code it would save, but it might help simplify the logic.

replies.bodyText:
It will make the fields ordering inside OrderBy clause to be not deterministic.
E.g. Presto query SELECT count(*), A, B FROM myTable ORDER BY A,B will make generatedPinot query to be  either SELECT count(*), A, B FROM myTable ORDER BY A,B or  SELECT count(*), A, B FROM myTable ORDER BY B, A.
I somehow feel it's better to keep the ordering as it is in case the underlying connector may take advantage on this(which is not there yet).
replies.author: xiangfu0

replies.bodyText: Oh okay. This is for Order-By !. I thought this is still for one of selections or outputs. Lets retain the linkedhashmap for order-by !.

timeline.bodyText: is it possible we make counter a private data member, and return counter here?
timeline.author: zhenxiao

replies.bodyText:
So the problem is that the Broker page source is one shot: It does not have a notion of partial or a cursor: Either the number of completed positions is zero or it is the entire number of rows being returned.
The current usage of completed positions (if you search for the callers of this function), is to basically show a progress indicator while the query is running. That does not fit the broker page source semantics: Because the counter will only change basically when the query is finished (ie when the counter is numRows, then the page source is already done and the query is being torn down)
replies.author: agrawaldevesh

timeline.bodyText: I think counter is completed positions?
timeline.author: zhenxiao

replies.bodyText: replied above.
replies.author: agrawaldevesh

timeline.bodyText: could outputs be Set? LinkedHashSet is an implementation
timeline.author: zhenxiao

replies.bodyText: I would very much like to keep it as a LinkedHashSet ... I can't tell you the number of times this has bit me: If order is needed then it should be statically checked.
replies.author: agrawaldevesh

timeline.message:
Support Pinot new SQL endpoint for broker queries.
- Enable this feature by setting `pinot.use-pinot-sql-for-broker-queries=true`
- Support aggregation/group by/oder by pushdown to query Pinot broker

Support Pinot new SQL endpoint for broker queries.
- Enable this feature by setting `pinot.use-pinot-sql-for-broker-queries=true`
- Support aggregation/group by/oder by pushdown to query Pinot broker
